variant.question: Where on the wings of heavier-than-air aircraft shall registration marks be located?

options.text: On the left half of the lower surface of the wing structure
On the left half of the upper surface of the wing structure
On the right half of the upper surface of the wing structure
On the right half of the lower surface of the wing structure

variant.question: The color identification of the contents of droppable containers and packages containing survival equipment should take the form of coloured streamers according to the following code

options.text: blue for blankets and protective clothing.
yellow for medical supplies and first aid equipment.

variant.question: A series of green flashes from aerodrome control directed towards an aircraft on ground means:

options.text: stand by, clearance for take-off will be given in short time.
slow down taxi speed, but continue.

variant.question: While taxiing, an aircraft receives the following light signal from the control tower: series of green flashes. This signal means that the aircraft:

options.text: may continue to taxi towards the take-off area.
must return to its point of departure.

variant.question: A steady red light from aerodrome control tower directed towards an aircraft on ground means:

options.text: move off the landing area or taxiway and watch out for aircraft.
vacate manoeuvring area in accordance with local instructions.
permission to cross landing area or to move onto taxiway.

variant.question:
Some letter combinations shall not be used in registration marks
Which of the following combinations might be confused with an urgent or distress signal?
What is the meaning of the sign 3 seen in an airfield signal square?
When letters are used for registration mark, combinations shall not be used which might be confused with urgent signals, for example
A series of red flashes from aerodrome control directed towards an aircraft on the ground means..

options.text: taxi clear of the landing area in use.
give way to other aircraft that are taxiing.
the aircraft is on the wrong taxiway and must stop and taxi back.

variant.question: Which of the following describes a 'Location sign'?

options.text: Yellow writing on a black background.
Red writing on a white background.
White writing on a red background.
Red writing on a yellow background.

variant.question: A runway-in-use for landing operations has been selected for noise abatement purposes. For this runway a full ILS CAT I is available and the runway condition is reported dry. The surface wind is calm, the visibility is 5 000 m and the ceiling is 5 000 ft. This runway-in-use can:

options.text: Be refused by the Pilot-In-Command for safety reasons.
NO longer be used when the ceiling lowers to 2 500 ft.
Still be selected for this purpose with a Localiser-only approach.
NO longer be used when the visibility decreases to 2 500 m.

variant.question: How are restricted (R), prohibited (P) and dangerous (D) areas represented?

options.text: By the letters R, P or D and additionally with an ID number.
By the letters RA, PA or DA and additionally with an ID number.
By the letters R, P or D.
By the letters RPD and an ID number.

variant.question: The identification for prohibited, restricted and danger areas is composed of:

options.text: the state territory indicator, followed by the letters P, R or D, followed by an ID figure.
the state territory indicator, followed by the letters P, R or D.
the letters P, R or D for the area concerned, followed by an ID figure.
the letters P, R or D, followed by an ID figure.

variant.question: What is the standard colour code for an ATC document when considering the aeronautical information circular (AIC)?
What is the standard colour code for a danger area map when considering the aeronautical information circular (AIC)?
A sign close to a taxiway, which indicates an ILS critical area, is a/an...
What two colours are Emergency Vehicles marked?
Where should a NO ENTRY sign be placed?

options.text: On site and on both sides of the taxiway.
50 m before the site on both sides of the taxiway.
On site and on the left.of the taxiway.
50 m before the site on one side of the taxiway.

variant.question: What is the colour of flags used to mark obstacles on airfields?
Which of the following statements regarding Type B runway holding markings is most correct?

options.text: Used when there is more than one holding point before a Cat 1,2,&3 runway.
Used for Cat for Cat 2 & 3 runways not Cat 1.

variant.question: A black letter "C" on a yellow background indicates:

options.text: the location where visiting pilots should report.
the location of the control tower.
the location of ATC on an airfield.

variant.question: Mandatory instructions signs on an aerodrome shall have the following colours:

options.text: white inscription on a red background.
yellow inscription on a black background.
black inscription on a yellow background.
black inscription on a red background.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 In accordance with ICAO Annex 14, what does the attached sign mean?

An aircraft is taxiing to the holding point of runway XX. CAT II/III is in progress. If the pilot crosses the ILS critical area, such action can lead to:
1) Pilot deviation.2) Operational deviation.3) Pilot can cross ILS critical area without clearance.4) The PIC must report such action to the approach control after departure.

Refer to figure 010-02.
The symbol number 5 is:

options.text: a holding position sign for aircraft.

variant.question: Other than location signs, aerodrome information signs must consist of..
A horizontal white dumb-bell with a black bar placed perpendicular to the shaft across each circular portion placed in the signal area indicates that:

options.text: Aircraft are required to land and take off on runways only, but other manoeuvres need not be confined to runways or taxiways.
The aerodrome is being used by gliders and that glider flights are being performed on a parallel runway.
Aircraft are required to land and take off on runways and all other manoeuvres need to be confined to runways or taxiways.
A parallel runway system is used at this aerodrome.

variant.question: Which of the following is not a mandatory instruction sign?
In accordance with ICAO Annex 14, the inscription on a runway-holding position sign at a runway-holding position shall consist of...

options.text: the taxiway designation and a number.
a location sign and a number.
the taxiway deisgnation and a direction sign.
a location sign and a runway headiing sign.

variant.question: A pattern 'B' runway-holding position marking at an intersection of a taxiway and a precision approach RWY shall be supplemented

options.text: with a category I, II or III holding position sign, as appropriate.
only with a runway designation sign.
with a category II or III holding position sign, though for CAT I runways a sign is NOT mandatory.

variant.question: Which of the following aerodrome ground signals displayed in the signals area indicates that glider flying is in progress?

options.text: A green ball suspended from a mast.
A black letter - C - on a yellow background.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.  
  What is the name of the sign?

options.text: Do not proceed without clearance sign.

variant.question: According to ICAO Annex 14, when mobile objects are marked by colour, which colours should be used for emergency vehicles?
Alternating taxiway centreline lights shall show ___ and ___ from their beginning near the runway centreline to the perimeter of the ILS/MLS critical/sensitive area.
According to Annex 14, aircraft stand markings shall be located over:

options.text: A paved apron and on a de-icing/anti-icing facility.
Any ramp area and on a de-icing/anti-icing facility.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Where may a Road Holding Position Sign be found?
Alternate yellow/green centreline lights of a taxiway indicate:

options.text: an ILS / MLS critical / sensitive area.

variant.question: Information signs other than location signs shall consist of
Select two colours that emergency vehicles should be marked with: - red - yellowish green - yellow - blue
In accordance with ICAO Annex 14, the only signs present on the movement area utilising the colour red shall be...
Where do you find a road holding position sign? At an intersection between...

Refer to figure 010-06.
The attached sign is a:
A NO ENTRY sign shall be located...

options.text: at the beginning of the area to which entrance is prohibited on each side of the taxiway.
at the beginning of the area to which entrance is prohibited on the left side of the taxiway.
50 m prior to the area to which entrance is prohibited, on each side of the taxiway.
50 m prior to the area to which entrance is prohibited on the left side of the taxiway.

variant.question: A red square panel with a yellow strip along each diagonal, displayed in the signals area of an aerodrome indicates:

options.text: aerodrome is unfit for aircraft movements, and landings are prohibited.
normal safety services are not available.

variant.question: A pattern "A" runway-holding position marking shall be supplemented at a taxiway/runway intersection with a..

options.text: taxiway designation sign only for paved runways.
runway designation sign only for precision approach runways.

variant.question: When shall runway signs be illuminated?

options.text: At night, in association with instrument runways.
At night, on non-precision approach runways only.
In runway visual range conditions less than 1 000 m.

variant.question: Describe the location of NO ENTRY signs:

options.text: Immediately before the prohibited area on both sides of the taxiway.
50 m ahead of the prohibited area, on both sides of the taxiway.
50 m ahead of the prohibited area, on the left side of the taxiway.
Immediately before the prohibited area on the left side of the taxiway.

variant.question: The white dumb-bell with black perpendicular bar indicates that:

options.text: While on the taxiway when approaching a runway.
While approaching a runway in flight.
On all taxiway intersections showing the direction to the next active runway.

variant.question: The runway holding position signs are constituted of...

options.text: a location sign and a runway heading.
a location sign and a number.
a taxiway designation and a runway direction.

variant.question: Where should an airport display aircraft stand identification marking?

options.text: On any paved parking and de-icing area.
On any parking area and de-icing area.

variant.question: Two or more white or yellow crosses, displayed on runways (taxiways), indicate that:

options.text: the section of the runway or taxiway is unfit for aircraft movement.
the runway or taxiway should be used in emergency only.
the runway or taxiway should be used with caution.

variant.question: In accordance with ICAO Annex 14, which sign indicates a location beyond which a taxiing aircraft would infringe an ILS critical/sensitive area?

According to ICAO Annex 14, aerodrome mandatory instruction signs are:
1. Runway designation signs,
2. Runway exit signs,
3. Category I, II or III holding position signs,
4. Runway-holding position signs,
5. Road-holding position signs,
6. NO ENTRY signs,
7. Direction signs,
8. Location signs
Red colour is allowed to be used for the following aerodrome sign...

Refer to figure.  
  The basic holding position shown in the figure will be used:

options.text: at an intersection of a taxiway and a non-instrument, non-precision approach or take-off runway.
where two or more taxi-holding positions are provided at an intersection.
when the red light stop bar is not available.

variant.question: A runway-holding position marking shall be established on...

options.text: a taxiway intersecting a runway and on a runway intersecting another runway if the runway is part of a standard taxi route.
a taxiway intersecting a runway and a runway intersecting another runway, if the runway is only used for landing after the intersection.

variant.question: Where are taxiway centreline lights showing alternating green and yellow installed?

options.text: From the beginning of a taxiway near the runway centreline to the perimeter of the ILS/MLS critical/sensitive area.
On that parts of taxiways which are not separated from a runway within the perimeter of the ILS/MLS critical/sensitive area.
On that part of the apron being under control of an apron control unit.
On all taxiways within the perimeter of the ILS/MLS critical/sensitive area.

variant.question: When displayed in the signal area or at the end of the runway strip in use, a right-hand arrow of conspicuous colour indicates

options.text: that turns are to be made to the right before landing and after take-off.
that standard turns in the circuit have to be made to the left, gliders have to make the turns to the right.
that 180 degree turns on the runway for backtrack have to be made to the right.
the position of the Aerodrome Reference Point.

variant.question: What should airfield signs be made out of to minimise damage to aircraft
You are flying in a mountainous region and you see a symbol "X" on the ground. What does this mean?

Which signal indicates "Operations complete"?

Containers or packages containing survival equipment for dropping should have the general nature of the content indicated by a colour code
